Award.AwardTitle: Elucidating the genetic determinants of organ identity using the C. elegans reproductive organs as a model
Award.AbstractNarration:
How cells acquire their identity is a fundamental question in Developmental Biology and one that has gained additional importance in the era of stem cell biology. In order to harness the potential of adult stems cells, the genetic factors that give them their unique potential must be understood. This potential is intimately linked with their tissue of origin. In this project, the reproductive organs of the worm Caenorhabditis elegans are used as a model for defining the genetic determinants of organ identity. All somatic tissues of C. elegans reproductive organs derive from two somatic gonadal precursor cells (SGPs). The SGPs undergo a set of cell divisions to generate five mature tissues in the female organ or four mature tissues in the male organ. The potential to generate these particular cell types is imparted to the SGPs at their birth; their sister cells differentiate shortly after they are born. A combination of molecular, biochemical, and genetic experiments will be used to incorporate newly identified genes into a genetic model for organ identity and to identify critical early regulators of SGP identity.

The outcome of this work will be a more complete understanding of the genetic controls of organ identity and multipotency, which has the potential to impact significantly the basic understanding of all stem cells, including human stem cells. An integral part of this research project is the development of an advanced undergraduate genetics lab course that will introduce students to inquiry-based research. In addition, this project will provide training for future US scientists, in that several undergraduate students, two graduate students, and one postdoctoral fellow will be engaged in conducting the research in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to learn the genetic and molecular factors that determine the identity and developmental potential of a cell. Embryonic stem cells are pluriopotent, meaning that they can give rise to all tissues of the developing embryo. Adult stem and progenitor cells are multipotent and are capable of generating a specific array of cell types. This project uses the Caenorhabditis elegans somatic gonadal progenitors (SGPs) as a model. The SGPs are multipotent progenitors that give rise to all somatic tissues of the reproductive system, including five distinct tissue types. Using this simple model, we found that: 1) different chromatin remodeling complexes are required in multipotent progenitors and differentiated cells of the somatic gonad and 2) sequence specific transcription factors act together with chromatin remodeling complexes to determine the identity and multipotency of the SGPs.

DNA is packaged into chromatin and this packaging makes some genes more accessible than others. Chromatin remodeling complexes regulate which genes are available for transcription in a particular cell type. SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes have been purified from a variety of mammalian cell types. Different SWI/SNF complexes are present in embryonic stem cells, neural stem cells, and differentiated neurons, suggesting that these complexes are regulating the potential of each of these cell states. Similarly, we found that different SWI/SNF complexes are acting in multipotent progenitors and differentiated cells of the C. elegans somatic gonad. This result suggests that similar mechanisms are controlling the transition from multipotency to differentiation in the C. elegans somatic gonad and the mammalian nervous system. Furthermore, we identified two sequence specific transcription factors that work together with SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes to determine the identity and multipotency of SGPs. This work establishes the C. elegans SGPs as a model for learning how SWI/SNF complexes interact with transcription factors to regulate multipotency.

An integral component of this project was the development an advanced undergraduate genetics laboratory at North Carolina State University. This course introduced undergraduate students to inquiry-based research and it prepared them to enter research laboratories with the skills necessary to be productive researchers. The project also provided training for seven undergraduate students, including one student that is a member of an underrepresented group (African American). The students learned current genetic and molecular biology techniques and they developed important skills that will benefit them in their future careers in science. Three of these students are currently enrolled in graduate programs in the biological sciences.
